title: How do anatomical constraints affect visual word identification?
abstractText:
When one focuses on the middle of a printed word, the letters to the left of fixation are initially registered by the right hemisphere of the brain, and the letters to the right by the left hemisphere.

The widespread assumption has been that word identification doesn't begin until all of the letters have been received by the (language-dominant) left hemisphere. This is made possible by very rapid interhemispheric transfer, which permits "early-integration" of the hemispheres. Recently, however, it’s been claimed that word recognition starts prior to interhemispheric transfer, with each half of the brain trying to guess the word’s identity based on the letters to which it has access (the "late-integration" account).

This project involves three experiments that will test this idea by measuring readers' reaction times to isolated words. By varying where readers fixate within a word it is possible to manipulate both the amount and usefulness of information to which each hemisphere has access in the earliest stages of processing. The standard ("early-integration") account predicts no effect of this difference in the input to the two hemispheres, whereas the "late-integration" account predicts that reaction times will be slower when the inputs to individual hemispheres are less informative.
